Title.evidence: Residual neuromuscular blockade (RNB) is linked to an increased risk of perioperative adverse events.

Intervention.evidence: The meta-analysis revealed that sugammadex facilitated faster reversal of RNB compared to neostigmine.

Objective.evidence: This study systematically evaluates the impact of neuromuscular blockade antagonists on postoperative complications and quality of recovery in surgical patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The meta-analysis revealed that sugammadex facilitated faster reversal of RNB compared to neostigmine, as indicated by a quicker recovery to a Train-of-Four ratio (TOFR) ≥ 0.9 (standardized mean difference [SMD] −3.45; 95% confidence interval [CI], −4.42 to −2.48), a shorter extubation time (SMD −1.44; 95% CI, −2.02 to −0.85), and a decreased incidence of RNB (risk ratio [RR] 0.18; 95% CI, 0.07 to 0.47).

Harms.evidence: Moreover, sugammadex significantly reduced postoperative complications compared to neostigmine, including the incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) (RR 0.64; 95% CI, 0.46 to 0.88), postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) (RR 0.62; 95% CI, 0.38 to 0.99), and bradycardia (RR 0.32; 95% CI, 0.20 to 0.50).
